intro: Phoradendron leucarpum subsp. angustifolium, commonly known as the narrow-leaf mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of host trees, primarily in the southeastern United States. It has small, oval-shaped leaves that are typically 2–5 cm long and have a leathery texture. The plant produces small, white or pale green flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences. Its berries are usually red or yellow and contain seeds that are dispersed by birds. This species plays an important ecological role in its habitat by providing food for various wildlife species.
